Jay Trace GILLIOZ, Maurice Earnest Mar. 6, 1877

Rolla, MO Apr. 18, 1962

St. John's Hosp.,

Springfield,

Greene Co., MO Research Note: Son of Alfred Gillioz and Josephine Bushman. His wife was Mary E. Moret and she was the informant on the death certificate. - Bio by Audrey Burtrum-Stanley / Arkansas - Gillioz first worked for the FRISCO RAILROAD. He then made his name as a contractor of bridges and roads. (Many bridges and roadways still bear plaques acknowledging the structure having been built by GILLIOZ CONSTRUCTION.) Gillioz became diverse in his business interests - and though today some of his structures are memories, his name is attached to two of the most beautiful buildings in Southwest Missouri. The 'GILLIOZ THEATER' in Springfield, Mo. opened Oct 11, 1926. It was both a theater as well as a movie house. Several films held their premiers there. Today, it is on the NAT. HISTORIC REG. and was restored to its grand glory. M.E. Gillioz also built the 'FOX THEATER' in Joplin, Mo. It was designed in the then-popular 'Spanish Revival' style. It opened in 1932. Today, it has been converted into a family center for the CENTRAL ASSEMBLY CHURCH. Gillioz also built the huge drive-in located in Monett, Mo. and several other structures in the community. Gillioz also owned and operated the GILLIOZ BANK and TRUST on Main St. in Monett. It was eventually sold to a larger banking chain. - Gillioz Plot Stone Death Certificate

Bio

Jay Trace GLASS, William James, Jr. Feb. 2, 1914

Sissonville,

Kanawha Co., WV Aug. 16, 2009

TX Research Note: He was the son of the late William James Glass, Sr. and Pearl (Milam) Glass. He graduated from Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, PA and then enlisted in the United States Army and served his country during World War II. He was honorably discharged after the war at the rank of Major. Dr. Glass married Maurine Curtis on April 9, 1943 in Abilene, TX. Maurine was born on November 25, 1922 in Weatherford, TX, the daughter of the late Harry A. Curtis and Pauline (Johnson) Curtis. It was after the war when Dr. and Mrs. Glass moved to Charleston, West Virginia where he practiced medicine until they moved to Monett in 1956. They purchased a building on Broadway and served the community until his retirement in 1982. During their years in Monett, they were members of the First Christian Church. It was in 1990 when Dr. and Mrs. Glass moved to Nixa, MO and in their later years moved to Denton, TX to be closer to their son and daughter-in-law. Dr. Glass passed away on August 16, 2009. Maurine Glass passed away on February 26, 2004. Survivors include one son, of Sanger, TX; one daughter, of Phoenix, AZ; four grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren. They were preceded in death by one son, William Curtis Glass. After the services, the family invites friends to stay for visitation at the funeral home. A private committal of ashes will take place at the Monett I.O.O.F. Cemetery. Buchanan Funeral Home

Bass of Monett, was lodged in jail Tuesday, on a charge of snatching a ladies hand bag in the city last week. His partner Emmett Granger made his escape. - December 28, 1916, Thursday, Cassville Republican - Sheriff G. M. Brixey returned Saturday from Bolivar where he went after C. G. Beaver who was wanted in this county on a charge of obtaining money under false pretenses. At Monett on his return he picked up Emmett Granger, charged with robbery of the Davie and Chappell store at Monet some days ago. Granger was arrested in Kansas City and brought to Monett by officer Smerdon and turned over to the sheriff. Beaver's preliminary comes up today, Wednesday, in Monett. Granger waived his preliminary and his trial will come up at the March term of the circuit court. - January 13, 1917, Saturday, Cassville Democrat - Saturday, Jan. 6, Judge Henson and Court Stenographer McClure of Mt. Vernon, came over and held a special term of circuit court, his first term in this district, and accepted the plea of guilty of Emmett Granger of Monett, for burglary and larceny for which he received four years in the penitentiary Sheriff Houston left Sunday night for the capitol city taking Granger with him. - Granger Plot Stone Death Certificate

Dade Co., MO Feb. 24, 1970

University of CA

Medical Center,

San Francisco, CA SSW: Dollie - Research Note: Usual residence was Martinez, Contra Costra, CA. James Greer, son, was the informant on the death certificate. Only son of 5 children of Oliver Patterson Greer and Queen Victoria Triplett. James Leonard Greer was married twice, the first spouse, Laura Serena "Dollie" King, dying early in life. Married Oct. 7, 1913 in Lockwood, Dade Co., MO. Second wife was Wilma W. (Wallin) Gregor. R. C. Akin's notes: Leonard and Wilma owned and operated a Tourist Court, just outside Springfield, MO on Route 66 called Lone Star Tourist Court. In my early years, we visited and stayed at the Tourist Court many times. They were quite old at the time but were very wonderful people. Aunt Wilma used to always make me a loaf of fresh bread, hot from the oven and I would sit and enjoy it in the tiny restaurant they had at the court where Wilma would also cook up hamburgers and make sandwiches for guests and passerby's, as they also sold gas outside the court. One of my memories was watching her washing the linens for the rooms in the back room of the office in an old open tub, top wringer, washing machine. She would hang the linens in the open air behind the court. It was always wonderful crawling under those fresh sheets at night. After Wilma died, the Tourist Court was sold, Leonard went to live with his son James Leon in Contra Costa County, CA where Leonard later died in the hospital in Martinez, CA. He was removed back to his home state for burial with his first wife, Dollie. Death Certificate
